This is the same item as hippiegunnut's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12307, tweaked very slightly with an optional lid added. -- UPDATE 4/13/2013 -- I added a second type of box: now you can use a sliding lid. Prints nicely, with a very steep angle in the lip so no overhang problems. I'm using these as chess boxes, card deck boxes, screw sorters, etc. Still fully parametric, of course. -- UPDATE 5/6/2013 -- Okay, finding a lot of uses for this recently. :) I added a parameter to include a coin slot in the lid. Now it's a divided piggy bank too! (My 8-year-old son uses it to handle savings, etc. separately.)
Print. Put lid on box. Or slide lid into box, depending on what you printed.

comments.text: Fyi, I am working on and updated version based of this file at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2594893. More options and variables to fiddle with.
comments.author: pynej

comments.text: I'm going to use them for tea and herbs. Maybe it's possible to make parameter for labeling?
comments.author: Spotz

comments.text: Maybe I'm just being stupid, but I can't seem to find the Parametric version of the slide on lid type? I only see an openscad file for the standard lid, and there doesn't seem to be a variable for the other style lid in there.
comments.author: shadow651

comments.text: It's in the same openscad file. Just a boolean for which type of lid to use. This settings affects both the lid and the top of the box, because the box top has to be a little different for a slide-on lid, of course. :)

comments.text: When you print other models with nesting parts, such as lids or pegs/holes, do they fit? If not, then the width of your extrusion is miscalibrated in your slicing software.

comments.text: I think that depends on the tolerance setting, and your printer's personality.  There's a variable in the SCAD file to mess with the tolerance, which should let the lid fit better.  Mine fits like a glove.

These clips are used to attach a PRINTinZ Zebra board to Printrbot Simple Metal. The clips recommended on their site have the possibility of falling off while printing. My clips are bolted down to prevent slipping off during printing.

Installation:
Print a left and right block. Remove any excess material / flashings from the part. Remove screws near front of the Simple printing bed, install the clip, and then reinstall the removed screws as shown in the photos.

The Fusion360 parts are attached if you want to modify them yourself.

comments.text: Yes, it is for the 168 mm x 237 zebra plate that's used for the printrbot simple metal.

description.text:
I want to give HUGE props to OpenForge and their amazing work! Their tiles inspired me to create my own tiles. I love the look of their tiles but I also am a tinkerer at heart and tend to want to change things. I created this set of tiles for you to easily customize any part of it, whether it's the size or shape of the boards or the spacing of the squares.
The total area is 2" X 2" for each tile (1" individual squares for minis to occupy) but I like to hook multiple pieces together in Tinkercad and print entire rooms at once. Reconfigure it anyway you like with any of my other designs (or message me if you'd like to see it put together a specific way and I'll gladly upload a new file) but please post pics of anything you print!

A connector for making BBQ skewer structures. Fit pretty snug - this version is a 'pass through' version meaning the skewers can go all the through (there is no wall stopping them).

Will upload the version with angles soon. If your using customizer the program is a little skewed - you'll notice x_number and y_number don't exactly correspond to the model.

UPDATE 2: Fixed! Made all the holes slightly bigger so it should fit now :) I found out it's possibly to insert a large coctail pick but then you would need to attach those to something :)  
UPDATE: just printed it, I really have to make the holes a bit bigger to make everything fit nicely :) But, having that said, it looks pretty good :) I'll update tomorrow.  
Well, what's there to say? This is one swinging Gnome! ;-)  
I left the top of the bars open so you can put a wire, rope or a rod through and hang multiple versions (in different colors!) amongst eachother :)   
Assembly should be easy and you can optionally glue the endstops. I think they will fit tight so it might not even be necessary.

print_settings.Notes:: I provided a version with manual supports which should be sufficient: Remove the thin walls below the hook and remove the U-Shaped support within the opposite hole. The red parts in the last image.

title: Latch lock for chest or sliding door

description.text:
A latch lock for chest or sliding door - linear movement. Works satisfactory.

-Easy to open by a push of a button
-No assembly required
-Quite robust

Screw holes have a diameter of 4mm.

Notes:

Please select proper printing orientation (see main cover image). Your printer must be able to bridge ~20mm.

I provided a version with manual supports which should be sufficient: Remove the thin walls below the hook and remove the U-Shaped support within the opposite hole. The red parts in the last image.

author: legobrix3xl

title: Peltor Tactical Headphone 1/8 Adapter

description.text:
"Make your tactical, practical!"
Convert your useless proprietary "Peltor Tactical Sport" Model # 97451 headphone connector to something useful like a 1/8" headphone jack. Use this part to adapt the radioshack part 274-0249 headphone jack into that funky space on your peltor tactical headphones. These are headphones model "Peltor 97451 Tactical Sport Hearing Protector" on amazon.

This object should let you put the radioshack 1/8" headphone jack directly in your peltor tactical headphones.  Solder the green wire as signal and black wire to ground. The black wire solders to the part of the jack closest to the wire on a headphone cable.  The outer two contacts should be shorted together and connected to the green wire.
Made for Ipod!  This is quite an intricate piece and it turned out very well.  To machine or cast this part would be a challenge!  3d printing to the rescue!
Hunt while you ipod..  This could be considered complimentary to the AR-15 Receiver.

tags: peltor headphone ar-15 ipod headphone adapter ear muffs plugs 97451

Geek Squad recently re-designed their iconic logo and launched it with the new Geek Mobile, the Prius C. This is a re-creation of the Prius' new nameplate using measurements I took from the Geek Mobile parked at Best Buy's headquarters and it seems to match up pretty well. The text is a little off as it was traced from the actual logo graphic, not pictures of the plate, but close enough. ;)

It could maybe use a 3-4mm straight extrusion off the back, but it's hard to tell since they won't let me remove the real deal from the new car.

I also made a couple of quick 5k wallpapers rendered through Fusion 360, they can be found at https://onedrive.live.com/?authkey=%21AJtzGWDbs3HxDWI&id=A03F96FA96D1A84%2140746&cid=0A03F96FA96D1A84

Unofficial design, created independently.

Le presse-agrumes Cupress, petit mais complet, vous facilitera la vie, puisqu'il intègre à la fois le presse-agrumes et un récipient plus pratique qu'à l’accoutumée, ainsi qu'une poignée réfléchie de façon à ce que le bec soit droit lorsque l'objet est saisi. Cupress vous permettra ainsi de réaliser vos jus aisément et sans efforts.

The Cupress juicer, small but accomplished, will make your life easier, because it integrates both the juicer and a more practical container, plus a handle thinked for the spout to be verticaly-positionned while the object is handled. Cupress will allow you making your juices easily and effortlessly.

Les logiciels utilisés / Used programs

title: Anti plastic curling gaurd mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Printable piece that can mount on the rods that hold the waste bin for the BFB 3000 and 3D touch.  Seems to almost eliminate curling molten platic from sticking to the hot end during warm-ups.
I modeled it based off of the center distance of the two highest pins on my printer (69.8mm).  I'm assuming they are all pretty much located in the same place on other machines.

Purchased parts: .010" brass shim stock
6-32 button head machine screws (x2) I attached a 1.375"x1.97"x.010" brass shim to mine with a tiny notch.
The notch I cut in is based on where the hot end parks during the purge cycle. The Brass shim is held by two 6-32 screws. All I had at home was some 6-32 screws(robertson). I'm sure button head SHCS would look nicer! Warning: on my printer it clears my fans no problem. I understand not all fans are mounted the same on BFB printers? So be sure that they clear by manully jogging the carriage. **Edit: I added a underside piece to ensure it stays in place (I noticed on mine it started to work it's self off). The new piece will work with this existing one. It simply bolts on underneath the existing one.

comments.text: I made this and did a modification. Instead of using brass, I used some 1/8" thick silicon rubber sheet. I also used the same material to replace the wiper that originally came with the 3D Touch, and I stacked two pieces of the rubber together for this new wiper -- it always cuts the oozing filament off at the start of the print -- no more dragging the ooze over onto the print bed. And no worries about crashing the hot end and its delicate reddish color insulation into a piece of metal. I shimmed up the silicon rubber piece with washers so that the top edge is right up against the hot end a fraction of a millimeter from the nozzle holes and the filament no longer gets bunched up on the nozzles. Works every time!
comments.author: tetralite

comments.text: Nice! I like it!

author: Syntaxcapt

description.text: Network video recorder (NVR) solutions in the market cost a fortune. Just a software license for NAS-based solutions are >$50/camera, and custom hardware solutions are in the thousands of dollars. So I decided to custom build-one. Total cost: about $140 (including SD card and power brick). That's less than just software license costs for four cameras (and there's CPU cycles to spare, for more cameras), and an order of magnitude cheaper than typical custom hardware! I used a Cubieboard2 (AllWinner A20 dual-core ARM, 1G RAM), a 2.5" 500G HDD, and Zoneminder. It can handle four standard-def (VGA) MJPEG streams (Foscam cameras) in modect mode (1 zone each) at 1fps, with cycles to spare (load avg is high due to I/O, but each core doesn't seem to go above 20% max, usually much lower than that). YMMV with different video formats and cameras. Cubieboard parametric model. In addition to the case, cubie-nvr.scad also has a model of the Cubieboard, with outward extension and slack parameters for connectors, so you could use it to cut out holes in your own case designs. Note that OpenSCAD seems to have issues rendering some parts in preview (F5), but all works fine in final render (F6).

Case
  • Print all three parts. Clean out holes. Test fit everything.
  • Insert four M3 nuts in base holes at bottom. Insert Cubieboard into base part. You may need to file audio jack holes slightly (PCB should be tight but should insert without force -- it you find you have to push too hard, then probably the audio jacks are not going through their holes).
  • HDD part screws onto bottom part. Use four long M3 screws and thread: HDD case part, spacer cylinders, then base part with PCB. Screw onto nuts previously inserted.
  • Insert SATA+power cable into Cubieboard, then insert HDD into HDD part, screw (6mm M3 screws, two are enough, you can use all four holes though) and route cables (it's tight, but they fit).
  • Lid is simply friction-fit. You may need to file rim corners slightly (just enough so it lid goes in, but not too much so it's loose).
    • The case was a quick job, to get the NVR together. It could conceivably be used without the HDD part (you'd just need to add a couple of mm height and modify lid dimensions). I was just in a hurry and too lazy to do these minor mods. Case isn't the cutest thing you've seen, but I was going for function over form (I wanted all ports easily accessible), and this was the only layout I could come up with that works. My HDD is a WD Blue 2.5" Slim drive, nice and quiet. Case should be ok with standard height 2.5" (not tested) and it should be easy to modify source. If you need a power brick, the Amazon Basics one is rated for 2A, decent quality, and just $9. Software These are not meant to be complete instructions, but this is a fairly standard install. Basically:
  • Install your distro of choice (I used Cubian, very nice -- installs on either SD or built-in NAND), configure network, create HDD partition and edit /etc/mount, etc etc. Note that you can assign the cubie a fixed MAC by editing /etc/network/interfaces.
  • Install zoneminder (apt-get install zoneminder).
  • Move zoneminder cache (/var/cache/zoneminder), log (/var/log/zm), and tmp (/tmp/zm) directories to the HDD partition. Update symlinks in web dir (/usr/share/zoneminder) and configuration (via web interface).
  • Set up Zoneminder following instructions for whatever camera you have (can't help you there, but there's lots of info on the web).
  • Move mysql data dir (/var/lib/mysql) to HDD partition and edit /etc/mysql/my.cnf accordingly.
  • (Re)start apache2, mysql, and zoneminder services, and make sure they come up on boot.

comments.text:
Hey, awesome project!
Didn't you have any troubles installing zoneminder on the Cubieboard? I've been trying over and over again, but there is always problems with dependencies.
comments.author: joaoduarte

comments.text: Do you think the RPI 2 would be powerful enough for an NVR?
comments.author: WestMD

comments.text: I haven't tried (it wasn't out when I built this), but based on specs it seems likely -- both are Cortex-A7, both have 1GB RAM, the RPi2 can be easily overclocked to 1GHz, and it's also quad-core instead of dual-core (Cubieboard2).  You'd still need an external USB enclosure for the HDD (and possibly a powered USB hub, although the RPi is better on the power rail front too).  It also depends how many cameras you want to run (e.g., for one, maybe two, cameras, even the original RPi should be fine, I think).
comments.author: WestMD

description.text:
Inspired by rrekwa's (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:750821) and others' designs for dual E3D T-bar style mount I created one more suited for single extrusion. This design allows you to have the E3D fan pointing back allowing for no loss of build area.

It also lowers the Vertex small fan and places it closer to the hot-end.

Needed
  • 4 M3 long machine screws and locking nuts
  • 3 M3 20 mm machine screws and nuts for the clamp.
Mounting the main piece to the carriage clamps (long screws)

I snipped four 61 mm pieces from an M3 threaded rod and used loctite (strong) with locking nuts (4 mm high) to create the screws of the required length.

Y end-stop

I cut a piece of plastic and super glued it to the underside of the xy bearing clamp so that it protrudes about 1 cm.

description.text: We got my daughters their own whiteboards to color on for Christmas, and I thought it would be fun to print out name plate magnets to stick on them.

Open up the blank in your 3D program of choice, extrude a name, and stick it on the surface of the oval, overlapping the vine.  Don't bother with booleans, just upload it to cloud.netfabb.com and let them sort it out.
I've also included the vine by itself.  If you need a longer name, you can copy the vine and rotate, mirror, what have you to make a larger pattern.  I printed mine on my Solidoodle, sanded the letters a little and painted them with nail polish.  I stuck adhesive magnet squares to the back to finish them off.

Original Posters Notes

.44 Revolver loading strips

Description

Loading strips for a .44 magnum revolver. These are meant to allow you to quickly load your revolver without use of a+ speedloader. I have not tested yet, but I suggest printing in a flexible material such as Flex PLA or Taulmans 618. ABS or ordinary PLA will most likely not work on this model. Print bottom down for best results. I was not able to get the exact dimensions between the chambers in the cylinder, so you may not be able to load two rounds at once as an ordinary one would allow. However, you can do one at a time and it will still be faster than if you do it by hand. Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: Printed on an Ultimaker 2+ with a 0.4 mm nozzle. Filament used was REAL PETG. It's probably a bad idea to use PLA for this application because of the possible high temperatures in the shower cubicle. ABS should be a an option as well. Nozzle temp was 240ºC and heated bed 30ºC (with 3D-LAC spray). As you would need 24 of these I suggest printing more than one per go and print them consecutively to minimize threading when printing PETG. Be aware tolerances are tight (otherwise there isn't sufficient friction). You should print a test part to see if it fits well and adjust part XYZ sizes accordingly.

title: Jacuzzi Flexa Tower jet knob replacement
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Jacuzzi Flexa Tower is a wonderful shower cubicle offering many functions, like hydromassage jets, steam bath and a fantastic water cascade. The 24 adjustable jets use round 'ring knobs' that allow the user to change the shape of the water jets. These rings have a tendency to split after a couple of years, possibly due to mineral build up. When they split they can't grip the nozzle sufficiently anymore. Enter the solution: print your own!
This replacement part has been designed to be easily printable and offering the same function as the original part. However it's not an exact copy of the original part. Printing them in transparant PETG imho creates a nice looking replacement part that should be a lot stronger than the original. :-)

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,10 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed with transparant REAL PETG at 240ºC nozzle temperature on a 30ºC heated bed using 3DLAC.

Printed on an Ultimaker 2+ with a 0.4 mm nozzle. Filament used was REAL PETG. It's probably a bad idea to use PLA for this application because of the possible high temperatures in the shower cubicle. ABS should be a an option as well. Nozzle temp was 240ºC and heated bed 30ºC (with 3D-LAC spray). As you would need 24 of these I suggest printing more than one per go and print them consecutively to minimize threading when printing PETG. Be aware tolerances are tight (otherwise there isn't sufficient friction). You should print a test part to see if it fits well and adjust part XYZ sizes accordingly.
PETG is a bit stringy but these are very easy to clean up in seconds using hot air or a knife.

Used digital calipers to get measurements. Sketched out the easiest to print shape and entered that in 123D Design. STL was imported in Simplify3D that was used to create a print file. Printed a test version which led to appropriate adjustments for the exact friction needed. Used Simplify3D to create a final print file with four knobs that print consecutively.

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: Lm8uu X Carriage with Fan Mount for Prusa Mendel

title: Lm8uu X Carriage with Fan Mount for Prusa Mendel

description.text:
This carriage has some differences from my other lm8uu carriage:

  • It is designed to work with nophead's half-belt hack: where the belt is either twisted or cut and joined such that the smooth side of the belt goes over the idler bearing (the teeth grippers on the belt clamps are on the other side).

  • It has a square(ish) hole so that it can accept my hotends that use 30mm aluminium tslot as a heat sink: http://i1236.photobucket.com/albums/ff455/gregfrost1/IMGP1349.jpg

  • The belt clamps are designed to use a single screw instead of 2.

  • It is slightly narrower than the previous version (to maximise x travel and get the fan a bit closer to the hotend heatsink).

  • Thanks to Triffid Hunter I have included a ram to protect the belt from the tensioning screw.

  • The double bearing is now on the side of the belt where it belongs (Less binding if binding is even possible with linear bearings).
    • Photo to follow (currently printing).
You are best downloading the files from my github: https://github.com/GregFrost/PrusaMendel as they will be kept updated and will have all the dependent include files.

description.text:
This Item was originally Posted by Defense distributed before they were made to take there downloads of there site by the US Government (Because they had working gun files) This is however not a working gun file

Original Posters Notes

ROCK CHUCKER DEPRIMER TRAY REPLACEMENT

Description

Cleaned up some interference on the fit and printing. Works for left and right models, PLA or ABS plastic.

The molded plastic “tray” that comes on recent RC with the 1″ ram tend to miss the primers and jam about every 100 rounds, then you spill the rest of them while trying to pull the sucker out of the frame. Attached files for 3D printed version that gets most of them into a 1/2″ plastic tube that goes down to a jug on the floor. Left hand and right hand versions are included.

Files are SCAD and STL format. Print with 3 perimeters, for strength, and enable support in your slicing program. 0.35 mm layer works fine, ABS or PLA. Get the thin vinyl clear tubing from local hardware store. It just pushes on the tapered nozzle.

Replacement for the inverted "Y" tray that is supposed to capture primers removed from cases on RCBS Rock Chucker Supreme.

This snaps into the same area behind the ram, but is retained by a lug in the slot and a ring that goes around the ram. Remove shellholder before installing or removing the tray. Select the version for a hose that goes on either the left side or right side of the frame, then down to a small bottle or plastic jug.

Source files include a"wHS" option "with Heat Shield" to keep the piece flat on the build tray for ABS, especially if your print table is small or slightly cold. The shield pieces can be easily trimmed off after the print cools.

Due to the nozzle, you will need to use support, but it can be 4mm or 5mm spacing. It simply rams out of the tube with a large hex key. Avoid using a flat-blade screwdriver. Hose is 4 or 5 feet of 1/2" or 13mm ID clear vinyl flex tubing available from local hardware store.

Print anywhere in the 0.25 to 0.35 mm layer height, ABS or PLA, with 0.3 rectilinear fill, at least 3 perimeters and 4 top and bottom layers.

Rappelant la forme d’un bouton de chemise au-dessus, vous ne pouvez pas vous tromper quant à la fonction de cette boîte. En effet, les 4 trous ronds peuvent accueillir des aiguilles à tricoter. Ensuite, vous pouvez ranger à l’intérieur de la
boîte tout le matériel nécessaire à la couture et au tricot.

Finis les câbles qui traînent sur votre table et qui s’emmêlent!
Avec la hidding box vous pourrez les ranger soigneusement en les enroulant autour du tube intérieur.
Les 4 trous sur la face supérieur et sur le coté permettent d’y faire passer 4 câbles différents. Pour les brancher il vous suffit de tirer sur le câble qui se déroulera autour du tube intérieur.
Pratique, elle se clipse à votre table et permet de cacher et trier vos câble.

It is a front sight base for VZ.58 rifle, which mounts on the barrel and holds the sight itself plus has the bayonet lug.

Measures should be accurate, since they are taken from the real thing. The depth of plunger pin hole is the only guestimate so far, hard to determine without taking the real weapon apart. I draw it as a learning experience – complex shapes, different methods, a tad of reverse engineering etc.

This is my steering wheel knob (or brodie knob) project for car (or boat)

I needed this to increase my capacity to maneuver my city car during the parking, as I had a small accident on my left hand. It worked very well, despite its simplicity.
I decided, in fact, to avoid bearings (not really necessary due to the limited number of turns it makes)

Here the list of the metallic parts: (all sizes in millimeters)

1 bolts M8 (80 x 8) (hexagonal head)
3 nuts M8 (6 mm thickness)
4 washers M8 (ext. diam. 15 mm.)

2 bolts M3 (20 x 3) (round head)
2 nuts M3

I added several versions, choose the model which correspond better to the section diameter of your steering wheel.

Edit 27/04/16: Added a new larger knob, if you need one (better grip, in case you have an heavy steering, like on a tractor). If you choose to realize this one you should also replace the main bolt, always a M8 but 100 mm length. The jaws remain the same.

Printer:

Ordbot Hadron

Supports:

No

Notes:

I made this in ABS, just to avoid problems with the sun heat (possible with PLA).
Printed with a 0.5 mm nozzle and 0.4mm layer thickness, without supports.
The filling was set at 25% for the jaws and 15% for the knob.

Important:

I had a comment concerning the safety and the legality of the knob.
Please note:
About the legality of the object please refer to your local legislation, I cannot be considered responsible if in your country its use is not allowed. (About USA, searching through each state's statutes, there were no laws in the 50 states banning the use of steering wheel knobs on regular cars. Nor in France, where I live. (internet sources))
About the security, the correct use of the safety belts avoids normally any contact with the steering wheel, and the knob position doesn’t prevent the regular operation of the Airbag.
More, as you can see in the project, the axis of the knob is not on the steering wheel but laterally, this mean that any bump on the top of the knob, if mounted in a non-excessively rigid manner, would make it rotate, further reducing the eventuality of a serious blow.
In any case is up to you to evaluate the risks. Drive carefully.
Regards

description.text:
I want to give HUGE props to OpenForge and their amazing work! Their tiles inspired me to create my own tiles. I love the look of their stuff but I also am a tinkerer at heart and tend to want to change things. I created this door for you to easily customize any part of it, whether it's the thickness of the door or the spacing of the boards. The door hinges might need some support to print but once it's all printed it snaps together without the need of shoving a paper clip or any other extra material to hold it together.
The doorway is 2" wide and a little over 2" high on its own but I like to hook multiple pieces together in Tinkercad and print entire rooms at once (as shown in the pics). Reconfigure it anyway you like with any of my other designs (or message me if you'd like to see it put together a specific way and I'll gladly upload a new file) but please post pics of anything you print!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5SHtoDyb08I

Original posters notes

HOLE PUNCH GUN

Description

The pieces of plastic in the video in no way make up a firearm. This is a desktop toy, and is a single hole punch that can punch through 2 sheets of paper at a time. Think of this design as an elaborate hole punch.

The current model weights in at 50.1 grams and costs roughly $0.75 to make.

This printed model pictured is the third version of the hole punch. It is composed of 5 pins, the bolt, the receiver, the trigger and sear.

This project is not yet completed. The bolt head is not long enough to punch paper, and the rubber band should not be wrapped around the gun, instead attached somewhere near the muzzle.

See assembly video here: youtube.com/watch?v=b6bk4KfecXE

title: Spring-loaded tool holder for Prusa i3

description.text:
This all-purpose spring-loaded tool holder fits the extruder mount holes on the X carriage of the Prusa i3. It should handle rotary tools (Dremel, Micromot), engravers and can accommodate Sharpie and etch-resist pens. The only disadvantage of this design is the very large Y offset, which reduces the usable Y axis by 55mm. This should be addressed in the next iteration.  
Spring tension is adjustable. Works with #6 machine screws, may also work with M4 parts (see instructions)

Tools needed: flat fine-cut file Parts needed:
Two #6 round-head machine screws, 2" or longer (with hex nuts) or M4 equivalent.
Two compression springs, the lighter the better.
One medium hose clamp (depends on tool)
One larger hose clamp (depends on tool)
machine screws used for extruder mounting (#6 round-head, 1" or M4 equivalent)

  • Print the inner channel (B-toolhead-inner.stl) with support structures enabled so it can be printed vertically. I have used ABS for both. To remove support structures from within hose clamp slots and nut trap slots, use end of needle file or small screwdriver.

  • Print the outer channel (A-toolhead-outer.stl) normally (no support structures needed). Some warping may occur on the foot plate but this should not pose a problem.

  • Check the fit of the inner channel within the outer channel. It should slide freely without sticking and should be a close fit (no wobble). File lightly until they can slide freely - it should only be necessary to remove the small ridges left as a result of printing vertically.

  • Assemble nuts in slot traps with machine screws and compression springs. Adjust screws so tension is as desired (tighter tension for milling, lighter for plotting and engraving).

  • Position tool in slot so tip does not come all the way down to surface of print bed when Z-axis is homed.

  • Put a piece of particle board on top of the print bed and note the Z offset.

This crate is designed by Joris van Tubergen in the ProtoSpace FabLab, Utrecht (Netherlands). We use this crate for storage of a lot of stuff.
The design is made for 4mm plywood, and just fits in the Epilog mini helix 12x24 inch laser.

You need 4 plywood sheets (4mm), 300x600 mm.
Use the laser settings as mentioned in the file for a Epilog mini helix 35 Watt. Put the parts together by using the tapered pieces.

Want to make your own clothes? Have a Makerbot? :) This is a design from a chilean designer called Mauricio Rojas, design is called "Telar para Valentina". I (my makerbot) made the plastic parts. This is a work in progress (soon I will add the details for the wood) I used aprox 1 lb. of white abs 3 mm plastic (pieces printed in 30% fill). About 4 days of printing (20 hours). The big parts (regletal.stl) require a very nice calibrated machine, this is why I used: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14174 to achieve outstanding quality!

1) Print 20 regletasmall2.stl (10 times this file)
2) Print 10 regletal.stl
3) Print 2 gotaengrane_fixed.stl
4) Print 8 thumb screw http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11848
5) Details for the wood: (pending)
6) Assembly: (pending)

title: Open Face Weighted Companion Cube Mold

description.text:
I made this mold in MeshMixer and plan to print with PLA, then pour molten Pewter into the mold. I simply imported the STL into MeshMixer, did a "Make Solid Offset" and then a plane cut to make the face open.

I will post pictures after printed and after casting.

Finally got the pewter and cast it (after many interruptions.... watch out for fillers inside the pewter your melting down).

After the metal had been poured, I waited a little bit and then pulled the halves apart. the metal was nicely hardened and everything looks great so far. I found there is a chemical that makes PLA rubbery, I plan to soak the cube next and pull the rest of the little bits off.

Will post more pictures after it has cooled down and gets cleaned up

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

P3Steel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If you use supports, make sure they only come up enough to touch the bottom of the mold, anymore and there will be supports inside your old.

I scaled this one up just a tad to make the cast 60mm x 60mm. Printed solid, this mold is about 6.4oz

author: ndrobertson

title: Spring Flower, Butterfly and Bee Multi Purpose Picks

description.text:
You can use these cute picks for a variety of things.

-- Add them to a mini sprial vase . It is scaled at .4 of the original size. I picked it because it has a wider opening at the top. Surprise someone with a tiny vase of flowers.

-- Use them as toothpicks for an appetizer or decorative cupcake toppers ; use PETG (which is theoretically food safe although some argue that bacteria and could grow in the layers) or PLA.

-- Use them as garden markers to show where she has planted seeds.

-- You or a friend can use them as a hair pin.

You might like these other picks and sticks I have designed:
Football Party Picks
Spring Flower, Butterfly and Bee Multi Purpose Picks
Great Outdoors Swizzle Sticks and Picks
Labor Day Party Picks and Sticks
Say I Love You
Lucky St. Patrick's Day Party Picks and Sticks
Breast Cancer Awareness Collection
Holiday Party Picks and Swizzle Sticks

Even though these are meant for a hard filament I create these designs to encourage people to try out flexible filaments or get some new interesting colors of flexibles. For info on purchasing samples of 6 different types of flexible filament see flexyfilament.com
